lines.text: You men! PIGS!
Oh, no Mr. Davidson. Your God and me could never be shipmates. And the next time you talk to him you can tell him this for me, that Sadie Thompson is on her way to Hell!
I'd race ya to the beach if it wasn't for these pesky heels!
I've no doubt you've a sufficiently good opinion of yourself to bear mine with equanimity.

[making a toast]
Well, here's bubbles!

From now on you will be strong. There is to be no more fear. Radiant... beautiful... you will be one of the daughters of the King. That's what you are now, Sadie, one of the daughters of the King... radiant... beautiful.
I understand, Miss Thompson. I'm sorry for him and I'm sorry for you.
I'm sorry, for everybody in the world, I guess.

[complaining about the dancers]
Mr. Horn, is this sort of thing general in your store?
Well, it's a general store, maam.
How you talk? What do you say? My husband is a very good man.
By the way, Officer, I was wondering, how does Pago Pago mean?
I don't think it means anything at all, sir.
Well, it's certainly well named.
Mr. Horn, your climate's bum!
Sorry, Sadie, it's the best we got.
Oh, I'm not blamin' you.
What can't be helped, can't be helped - as the sayin' goes.
I like the boys here. Hello, Handsome, when did you leave Kansas?
I hear life's terrible back home in the States now.
How so?
Everybody bein' made to behave.
Thou shalt not enjoy thyself.
Friend, you'll behold here the last remnants of an earthly paradise. That's my quarrel with reformers. They won't let it alone.
Yes, I can readily see how a reformer might feel a little out-of-place here. Sort of like a schoolmarm waking up in a harem.
Too bad man couldn't develop a soul without losing the Garden of Eden.
Oh, she-catta-gan-nee, she-catta-gan-nee, that's "I should worry" in Jap, buttercup.

[Sadie grabs a bottle of liquour]
I'll find a glass for you, Miss Thompson.
What for? Down the hatch!
[Puts the bottle to her mouth and takes a swig]
You're not the type that needs hooch to pep you up!
Oh, I was born hooch!
Music and a nip of liquor, that's what a rainy day is for, says I.
Can you dance, Handsome?
No, Miss Thompson. I'm a club foot. I never could twist my legs right.
Well, I'll learn ya before I leave. That's a threat!
We've all crossed thresholds we don't brag about.
You don't mind, do ya? Seein' we're here all by ourselves, if I sit down and have a skag with you boys?
Not at all
Have a drink!
No hurry. Lot's of time. There's so much time lying lose around this island, somebody ought to bottle it up and send it back to were they need some.
I'm alright. Don't you worry about me, a bit. You see, I'm a happy-go-lucky sort of a fellow. Its true, I'm broke now. But, that doesn't worry me.
Mighty glad you aren't sore at me, 'cause, well, I like to keep friends with everybody.
The devil in you is strong, my poor Sadie Thompson. Evil has claimed you as it's own.
You take care of your own evil and I'll take care of mine!
What's the matter? You look low.
Low? Maybe. It's this rain, I guess. Makes me jumpy. Makes me want to knock my head against the wall.
Anyone can see with two glass eyes that this side of the equator, he's in right and I'm in wrong.
You know, there's something about that old crow that isn't human. He's deep - creepy. I guess it's his eyes. They seem to look right into ya and know what you're thinking.

[Sarcastically]
Can't I just hear Lefty's wife yelpin' with joy at the sight of me.
Oh, you haven't any cause to worry about Maggie. You two would get along swell.
Baby boy, I know females. You don't.
I got an idea what's on your mind. But, Maggie ain't the kind of a dame you're meanin'. She's square from the toes up.
You mean this Maggie was sorta gay before Lefty came along?
I haven't so many friends, Handsome, but what I can do with one more. You know, you're an awful funny fella, Handsome.
I guess I'm the dumbbell king, alright.
You low-down skunk! What have you been telling the Governor about me?
I've been hoping to have another talk with you, Miss Thompson.

Why you miserable snail-snatcher! I wouldn't talk to you if you and me were the only two people left on earth. Why, you're so doggone mean it makes me sick even to look at ya! That's what I think of you! Coming to me with all that guff you spill about salvation. Then, goin' and havin' me deported on top of it! Why, you low lizard - !
You don't think I want to stay in this rain-hole, do ya?
You will be glad to hear that the Governor has acted, at last. He's a weak man. For days he had shilly-shallied, saying it was none of his concern.
Has she wondered why I haven't been around?
No.
Didn't you tell her, you ole pelican, that they had me in the brig?
I'm off to bed. There's an uncanny concentration about the rain tonight.
Hello, Miss Thompson. What are you up for?
I couldn't sleep. With this rain and those drums. And, then, thinkin' about tomorrow. I don't seem to be able to do much for myself, do I?
Surprised to see me all dolled up, heh? Well, why not? I had to put on my best, this gay and glorious morning, didn't I?
[Sarcastically]
Besides, I'm radiant! Beautiful! You didn't know that, did ya? I caught a gleam in my eyes when I saw that sun this morning. Do I feel fine? I do.

Why should I turn off my phonograph because Mrs. Davidson's coming back? I'm not concerned with what Mrs. Davidson thinks; or, for that matter, with what Mr. Davidson thinks. My advice to him is to pin on his wings and fly in the air.
Now look here. You may take the British lion by the tail. You may twist it. You may jerk it. You may yank it. You may tie it in a big bow knot. But, dash it all, you can't pull it out by the roots!

Everything goeth, everything returneth. Eternally rolleth the wheel of existence. Everything dieth, everything blossometh forth again. Eternally runeth on the year of existence. Thus sprach Zarathustra. Oh, good old Nietzsche.
